data.title: Best value for price
data.body: This controller has been working great for me. It's light and works smoothly. The only downside is not having a rumble function but that's fine by me.

data.title: Perfect for Modern Gaming
data.body:
I have owned this controller for about five months now and I can say without a doubt I made the proper purchase. It is cheaper than the Microsoft equivalents but works (assuming) just as well. I've logged 70+ hours playing Spelunky on this Bad Boy as well as 60+ with Euro Truck Driver 2 and I didn't have to change a thing in the settings. It worked as soon as the games turned on. And its the same way for every single other game I have played using it (at least 50+, I have a massive Steam library but prefer Keyboard/Mouse for first person games. Rouge Legacy, Dirt 2, Strike Suit Zero, Super Meat Boy, honestly the list could go on for ever but for every single one it was pick up and play using this controller).

I must add that I play first person games with keyboard and mouse so if you are looking for review that covers that in particular you may want to skip mine.

I have encountered one problem that is going to require a bit of maneuvering and fixing to make work properly. Not all older games subscribe to the "pick up and playness" that I referenced earlier. Honestly so far it has only been one game (GTA: San Andreas), but I'm confident I can fix the issues at hand. It just gives me pause when it comes to other older games that it wont be so easy to "pick up and play".

It fits nicely in my hands (I have very large hands so it may be different for others) and the buttons seem to have normal responsiveness. The triggers have the right amount of resistance so you can make the perfect shot. Cord length is also long and has never been a hindrance to my gaming experiences.

It has fallen to the floor a few times off of my desk or out of my sleepy hands but has zero cracks and it has not affected its performance at all. Durability has been great. Triggers still work like they did coming out of the box which is wonderful when you consider a game like Spelunky requires you to hold down the right trigger for speed the entire game.

So to recap; Every modern game I have played using it has been a seamless experience. It is as if it is a 360 or PS3 controller. The lone older game I have tried to use it with has been a little wonky to say the least but I am confident I can program it to work the way it has with modern games. I should also add works great with NES and SNES ROMS. I cant believe I had been playing ROMS with a keyboard for so long. A controller makes them infinity easier and just feels right, makes the whole experience a bit more nostalgic.

If you are put off because it isn't an official Microsoft or Sony product stop it. This controller works amazingly with all modern games (again I use keyboard/mouse for first person games so that might make this review completely worthless to you) and with a couple minutes of fooling around can be programed to work perfectly with older games as well.

I do not regret buying this in anyway shape or form. It is a perfect controller for me to dig into my obscene library of games. I'm very pleased with my purchase and would recommend it to a friend.

data.title: Good , Reliable, works out of the Box game controller
data.body:
Pros of the Logitech G F310 Wired Gamepad Controller:
1. Affordable: The G F310 is generally budget-friendly compared to other gaming controllers.
2. Versatility: It's compatible with both PC and popular gaming consoles.
3. Familiar Design: The controller has a layout similar to popular console controllers (PS2 Controller clone) making it comfortable for users accustomed to those designs.
4. Customizable Buttons: You can assign different functions to the buttons using Logitech's software. This is done by putting then controller in “D” direct input mode which is a switch on the back of the controller.
5. Even though the description does not mention this it does feature vibration feedback. This provides tactile feedback during gameplay, enhancing the gaming experience by adding a sense of immersion through vibrations corresponding to in-game actions.

Cons:
1. Wired Connection: Some users may prefer wireless controllers, and the G F310 is wired.
2. Build Quality: While decent, it may not feel as premium as more expensive controllers.
3. Limited Features: It lacks some advanced features found in higher-end controllers, such as advanced haptic feedback or gyroscopic sensors.
4. D-pad: Some users find the D-pad less precise and cheap feeling compared to other controllers.

Overall: Great controller for the price that is usually compatible with anything you can plug it into right out of the box but is also customizable. Most reassembles the Playstation console controllers look and feel.

data.title: Good controller
data.body: Works fine, not the greatest fine control with the joysticks, but good for the price.

data.title: A dependable yet affordable controller option
data.body:
Logitech is a really strong brand in the PC gaming community. I have been a huge fan of their gaming mouse, and their game pads. The game pad has a similar body style to the Play Station controllers did or still do (I stopped Play Station when 2 came out). I purchased this one because, it is updated to USB 3 from USB 2, which is nice when you are playing retro games or games you like to play on PC using a controller instead of a keyboard and mouse. On Windows, it is plug and play. Have to make some setting changes in Steam/Game you are using the game pad with.
The buttons are firm, not mushy, and are accurate when pressing. The dual sticks are great for top down shooters and are accurate in movement. Again, you have your trigger buttons and L R buttons. Since it is USB, you do not need to have batteries, and the force feedback is also a nice touch but easy to turn off if you do not want that feature on.
For 20.00 usd, it is a great buy and I highly recommend it.

data.title: Not ergonomic and buttons wear out fast, but costs almost nothing.
data.body:
A reliable standard that performs well while the buttons last. The good news is that an F310 costs almost nothing. The bad news is that you'll need to buy another one every other year, even with casual use. The buttons wear out long before the pad or joysticks.

Why three stars: form factor is too small. If you have large hands, platformers and twitch-reflex games with this controller hurt your fingers.

data.title: Good controller, just works
data.body: Bought to play some games on my PC which are better enjoyed with a controller. The joysticks are smooth so far and the buttons have a good tactile feel. I have pretty small hands and the controller is comfortably usable; although I would personally prefer something smaller, that's not an easy find, so this one is compact enough. Construction feels solid, no creaking plastic like I get from my old PS3 controllers.

data.title: Excellent controller at a great price.
data.body: Logitech continues to provide quality controllers; this G F310 has good response and clean movement and feels great in my hands—not too heavy, not too light. It's brought my gaming to a level where I can't blame the controller for my poor play!

data.title: Very good controller - if you understand what you are buying (quality-wise)
data.body:
This is a controller that I wanted to rate 5 stars, because it does exactly what I need it to do. The issue is, for most people this won't be a five star product - so lowering it to make sure expectations are set. The build quality is less than most controllers - even a default PS4 controller. You can tell by how light it is, and when you push buttons - especially the d button. If you are a heavy gamer, I think you would prefer something of a better quality.

Having said this, the price is incredibly low. I think it would be hard to find a controller this quality for a better price. I needed the controller for one game, and it has definitely served it. This might also be good for younger kids who break things easily - as if they break it, you are out only a small amount compared to most controllers.

This was a plug and play. I plugged it into my laptop and was ready to go. No setup or anything needed. For me, this is exactly what I wanted for a price I am really pleased with.

data.title: Freaking awesome
data.body:
While I have used controllers on my PS3 and 4, I have never had or used one for my PC. Since I have games that work so much better with a controller, this made a huge, huge difference. It performs as it should and my PC recognizes it and it works really well in the games I am using it for (Racing games).

I would have liked to give it a 5-star rating for ergonomics but I feel that the paddles are in an un-natural position for my thumbs. In a relaxed position, the paddles should be right under my thumbs, but in this case, that is where the A, B, X, Y buttons and D pad are. By comparison, my PS4 controller paddles are nearly spot on where they should be in relation to my relaxed thumb position. Not a deal breaker but it could be better.

I'm a Logitech fanboy and generally very, very happy with all of their products, this controller is no exception.

data.title: Perfect for Pandora’s Boxes!!!
data.body: I have a Pandora’s Box with over 10,000 retro video games. Using the stock joysticks was tough until I upgraded the springs to 6lbs. Some of the games were not made for Arcade style Joysticks. After trying a PS4, Xbox Controllers wired and Bluetooth, none of them would work. After searching the internet, especially YouTube for Controllers that work with a Raspberry Pi or Pandora’s Box. This specific Controller worked instantly and I didn’t have to adjust the settings either. Straight plugged it in the first USB Port and it worked! The price was perfect!

data.title: good but,
data.body: Everything works as expected however the shape is such that it gets uncomfortable holding it after a little while there isn't a lot of room for your fingers in the underneath the controller. The control sticks are placed just a little outside of where my thumbs would naturally rest so using them after a while strains your muscles. The buttons work very well, but I would have chosen to use a plus style directional pad rather than a disc Style, I find when I'm playing, i often unintentionally move diagonally. But it's very sturdy it has been dropped several times and still works just as good as new

data.title: Not my favorite, but great for kids.
data.body:
This remote connects perfectly with my computer. I used it a couple of times and everything worked great. I just don't like the feel of the remote. So, I went out and bought a new Xbox remote to use. However, I keep this remote close so that my kids can play their games on the computer and they don't need to use my other (more expensive) remote.

I am glad I purchased this for our family's use. I just personally didn't love it. The cost is very reasonable and I will not hesitate to purchase again WHEN my kids ultimately break this one fighting over who gets to play Lego Batman next!! 😀

data.title: It worked but the buttons started getting annoying
data.body:
I bought this around 2020. It worked for years. Eventually the bumpers/triggers became a bit unresponsive and needed to either be pressed multiple times or smashed to work.

The d-pad was always trash in terms of how it felt and how confident I was that it would do what I wanted, though it did work.

The buttons and controller shell always had a bit of a plastic creaking to it.

Eventually the red/b-button lost springy-ness, so I replaced it.

Overall, for the relatively low price, it's fine. However, there are probably better choices for similar prices at this point, so try looking around.

I'm giving this four stars rather than something lower, just because it did work for years and was cheaper than most listings at the time from what I recall.

data.title: Great for the price
data.body: I wish it had haptics but for the price I really can't complain. It does make a bit of a clicky noise though, it's not very quiet. But it works!

data.title: Worth the price
data.body: The joysticks are massive so they were a bit to adjust to. Also on initial use my character in the game would automatically walk as if I was pushing the joystick but I wasn’t.

data.title: UniTesT engineering
data.body: top-notch design and build quality, unfortunately must have been prior to hall joysticks and triggers were realized and implemented. returned because i can't hit squat. without hall engineering, forget-about-it.

data.title: No More Controller Drift !
data.body: For the longest time I was an advid user of Logitech's wireless controler, well, up until controler drift became too much of a hassle to deal with. I had been thinking of going old-school for a while and it was time. This controller does it's job, sacrificing wireless conveniece for fewer unwanted in-game mistakes was worth it in the long run. After all, I shouldn't have to go through the trouble of recalibrating my equipment every few months or weeks just to stay at the top of my game. It's just a shame that Logitech hasn't (or won't ?) upgrade their wireless controller and offer it on their website. Luckily this option was available despite getting it from a third party vendor, I'm a fan of Logitech and didn't cherish the idea of switching brands to get good results and I REALLY don't want to buy yet another console that I don't want just for a reliable wireles game controler. I've got a PC and a Steam account, I don't need to spend upwards of a thousand-plus dollars for a Playstation or an X Box and repurchacing the games I already have on my desktop's hard drive when the price of one controller fits my budget. The only complaint I have (which every gamer has had since the 1980's) is that the chord could be longer, but I don't have to put up with drift anymore, so I'm happy with the results regardless after a few weeks with this controller. Do I recommend this controller? Absolutely ! If you're tired of controller drift and can put up with the chord then go for it, it works well and it won't break the bank. Only thing is, it's lighter than you may be used to, no battery and no vibration feature seriously cuts down on the weight and will feel weird at first until you get used to it.

data.title: Works great
data.body: Not sure why you'd buy any other controller that costs around the same. It'll last you a long time and it works great. The other options look pathetic compared to this lol. Not the most comfortable to hold but everything else is great.

data.title: Great controller, frustrating clamshell
data.body:
I've been playing console video games for at least 22 years, right around the time I picked up a SNES controller on the family console for the first time in the early 90s. This continued through the late nineties when my parents purchased an N64, to the early 2000s when I purchased a PS2, 2007 when I purchased an Xbox 360, and continues to this day after I purchased an Xbox One a couple years back.

Why mention my extensive console gaming experience? PC gaming is a completely different animal. When you grow up on D-pads and analog sticks operated by a single thumb, trying to fit WASD into your head is a tall order. Here's a good analogy anyone can relate to: let's assume you are awesome at typing on a QWERTY keyboard, 150 WPM or some such. You get a job as a data entry technician, and when you sit down on your first day... they have DVORAK keyboards. What are the chances you're going to learn a completely new keyboard layout to do your job? None. You're gonna go to Wal-Mart on your lunch break and buy yourself a QWERTY.

Which segues into why I purchased one of these. I needed a gamepad for my PC because I simply could not adjust to the completely different hand placement and movement paradigm that comes with a PC video game. I kept losing my finger positions on the keys and high-stress situations (like attempting to dodge and exchange fire with an enemy on a shooter) were really getting me in trouble because three-finger movement on WASD was taking too long to process.

Adding to the complications are that my system is Linux, which is usually a no-go from the start because nothing ever seems to work on it. I decided to take a chance on this anyways because with Amazon gift cards and a Prime trial, I got it for $11.

To begin with, the package this controller comes in is a nightmare. It's a clamshell with no room to maneuver a pair of scissors or a razor blade around the controller inside, so you have to use the little tab and perforations on the back. Problem is, the perforations end halfway down where the controller is contained, so your only option is to tug on both ends and send your controller flying when the package inevitably bursts open. After collecting the entire contents of the package from the floor, all that's inside is a controller and two small squares of paper. I seemed to recall the product description mentioning software, so it must be online somewhere I suppose. Either that or I really sent a CD flying and can't find it.

But the moment of truth comes later, when you plug it into a PC. Does it work? As a Linux user, the answer is, surprisingly, yes.

I plugged in the USB connector and nothing happened. This either means the operating system knows exactly what it is and doesn't have to do anything, or you're SOL and need a driver or something. My eyes were drawn to the little Logitech logo on the center of the controller, and I decided to push on it to see if it was a button like the XBox Guide button on their controllers. It is! Steam's Big Picture mode launched and I needed no configuration or messing around with anything to make it simply work. On a Linux system. I was amazed.

So I decided to push my luck on a ROM using a program called Mednafen, which is a multi-system retro console emulator. Didn't work so well any more in Xinput or direct mode, though this is almost assuredly due to Mednafen's programming and not anything to do with the Logitech controller. I searched out the profiler software mentioned by the instructions to attempt to fix this problem, but after finding the Logitech support page I discovered that they only offer software to recent versions of Windows, so you won't get any help from them if you run another system. About 5 minutes of Google searching later and I find QJoyPad, and now everything is perfect.

This controller has a total of 12 buttons (2 bumpers, 2 triggers, click analog sticks, select, start, A, B, X, Y) and 6 axes (Dpad X/Y, left stick X/Y, right stick X/Y). The Logitech logo launches Steam Big Picture for me, but I have no idea if it will work on anything else. It has a very similar size and form factor to a PlayStation DualShock controller with fatter feet on the bottom, which I like because DualShocks are bony and poke my palms uncomfortably. You'll see the form factor is very similar in the attached photos, which I also placed alongside Xbox controllers for contrast and a pack of standard playing cards for scale.

data.title: The d pad has 8 separate switches.
data.body: Best dpad for fighting games that exists. Shoulder buttons are not great, analog sticks are probly not rad either. Dpad is 20/10. Buttons are 10/10.

data.title: Very easy to use
data.body: Plug and play! Very reliable, buttons feel nice and are responsive. Controller is a little large for my hands which can cause discomfort after extended use.

data.title: good stuff
data.body: maybe I'm just inexperienced with controllers but I've never noticed the uncomfortable feeling while holding that others report on. needed a quick replacement and this was a great cheap choice. wish it had rumble as well but otherwise it's a nice little guy

data.title: It works
data.body: It works really well for the price. Buttons are easy to press and don't get stuck, and the thumb sticks are nice and stable. If you need something good for emulators or Steam games, this is your best bet.

data.title: Great except the D-Pad
data.body: I love the controller but i wish the d-pad was separated like sonys instead of all together.

data.title: Quality at Lower Price Makes This Logitech Controller Solid Value
data.body: Overall, controller feels solid. Minimal effort to install. Only exception is vibration - still trying to find out how to get it working.

data.title: Good quality
data.body: The quality of the product is as good as the seller describe it.

data.title: Kid Friendly
data.body: Plug and play ease of set up and use.

data.title: This has a vibrate mode?
data.body:
I have yet to feel this vibrate on me.

Prior to writing this review I didn't think it had vibrate.

Works well. Good enough to control GTA, Call of Duty, and a Submarine.

data.title: Great for the price
data.body: Works fine with my older PC games from around 2000.

data.title: A solid controller at an affordable price
data.body:
There aren't many controllers where you feel like you're actually getting your money's worth, and for this one, it almost feels like you're stealing from the company.

The controls are responsive, the controller is durable and can handle being dropped pretty often, and it seems to work with nearly any device it can plug into.

All and all, I would say... if you don't have the cash to fork over for a high-end heavy-duty $100+ controller, then this would be the best option for you.

data.title: Good gaming controller for the price
data.body: You could pay $70-$100 for a Play Station, X box or a gaming controller or you could get this logitecj controller. I like Logitec products, they are affordable. The wireless Logitech gaming mouse I got for $20 is comparable to a $100 mouse. This does not really vibrate but who cares? It is sturdy and ergonomic.

data.title: Durable
data.body:
A good dependable controller, good enough to play a game, and tough enough to throw at a few walls.

There is no rumble on this controller though, but other than that, one of my favorite controllers.

data.title: Best budget alternative to a console controller I've found
data.body:
I wanted a controller for PC gaming for the rare title where a controller is really that much better than kb&m controls, but I wasn't about to shell out $80 for an Xbox controller and the adapter needed to use it for PC. This is the one I settled on, and after at least 100 hours of gameplay use from Hades alone I can say it's a quality controller.

Note that this does not have rumble capability of any kind, nor does it have some of the fancy speaker/microphone stuff Sony and Microsoft have started adding to their controllers. If you want all the bells and whistles of the expensive controllers - well, you're gonna have to buy one of the expensive controllers. But if you don't really care about that stuff and just want a well built controller with the standard modern Xbox/PS style layout, this one is a great choice. I have never had a game that supports controller input fail to map the controls correctly or anything like that. And if you install Logitech's profiler software, you can fully rebind the controls yourself - allowing you to correct annoying control setups in games that don't have built-in rebindable controller controls, or if you decide you want to use it for a game that doesn't even have controller support you can rebind the buttons to keyboard buttons so as far as the game is concerned you're just using keyboard controls. Not sure exactly how sophisticated the profiler is in terms of macros and the like because I've never bothered to install it, since this controller just works with no fuss for all the games I've tried it with.

It even has a toggle switch on the back to switch to directinput if you wanna play some ancient game that lacks xinput support (if you don't know what this means, don't worry about it - xinput has been the standard for years now and any remotely modern game with controller support is gonna use it).

All the buttons still feel good after 100+ hours of heavy use. I haven't noticed any issues with thumbstick drift, a problem even the "premium" controllers sometimes have. The d-pad is much higher quality than on most cheap controllers - it has 4 separate switches for the 4 cardinal directions instead of just one in the middle, so it is more reliable and feels better to use). The controller itself feels a bit lighter than an Xbox controller but still feels sturdy and durable.

I'll admit I'm a big of a Logitech fan, so maybe I was biased to like this controller - but there's a reason it's one of the most common recommendations for a budget PC controller and the top seller in the PC controllers Amazon category. If you're looking for a cheaper alternative to an Xbox controller, and don't mind a wired controller or lack of rumble support, this is the product you're looking for. At full MSRP of $24.99 it's a very good deal, and if you're patient and look for deals it's not hard to find in the 15-20 range at which point it's an absolute steal.

If you want a budget option that is wireless and has rumble support, look into the Logitech F710.

data.title: Great retropad for windows XP games
data.body:
To be honest the gamepad is great and can switch between Directinput and Xinput (if you don't know what it means, you don't need to switch it); which is great for XP and W98 games. Works nicely with a retro-machine set up with Windows XP, but works with modern computers too.

Ergonomics is pretty bad if you are used to Xbox controllers for example; but you get used to it after a bit.

data.title: Logitech game controller
data.body: It arrive on time and it works perfectly

data.title: Good enough I bought more
data.body:
Short version: Good enough for someone who doesn't controller all the time. Bought another to replace a +1 year old one.

Misc background. I main KBM ever since I started playing games on the PC, after I stopped really old games on my Sony Playstation 2 around 2010. No particular reason though just what I had. The controller on the left is from 2016 and as you can see mostly sat on a desk collecting dust after a combined week or two of Super Meat Boy, 20XX (a Megaman style game), and Streets of Rogue 2p local co-op with a friend. Those first two recommend controller, the reason I bought this. Despite how bad it looks it still sorta works.

That controller on the left really seen use after a year of Genshin Impact. It got real noticeable when the A button started collapsing and wouldn't reset consistently so sometimes I would jump again or select or try crafting something twice. The B button for attack was starting to get loose too. I guess I got lucky because I don't remember getting any stick drift unless that one premium $80 or something controller.

It was time for a replacement. That is the new one on the right after doing some weapon ascension material domains with it. Some things I didn't notice on the old controller as I was putting days with it, how grippy the plastic is before hours and hours of human sweat smoothed it, how the thumbsticks actually have textures on them, and of course how loose the more commonly used buttons were getting.

If you're a first time controller buyer this controller should suit most of you fine. I know some more controller heavy clanmates of mine have replaced Playstation and Xbox controllers (though they use them more so it's probably expected) but if you controller sometimes this could do fine. If you controller sometime but want a more premium experience I'm sure the $40 tier ones are good .

A con for the Logitech F310? I guess the triggers are pretty strong especially if you're an hour into Human Fall Flat night. Oh and no vibration. Shame. The $40 tier Logitech wireless controller/gamepad has force feedback but having to compare $40 tier controllers is a bit harder. There are a gorillion sub $30 tier controller manufacturers you can choose to buy from on Amazon, but there's only 1 Logitech.

I bought a USB hub and plugged it in the hub, under my monitor, so the cord length was plenty for me and whenever a friend would come over for some twin stick action.

data.title: PC game controller
data.body: This game controller works OK but the layout of how it held does not work as well as Xbox.

data.title: Excellent pc gamepad
data.body: Interesting to see reviews stating that this controller doesn’t work on Windows 11 pc’s… we’ve tried this on multiple Win 11 pc’s and it’s been simple plug & play w/o any issues at all… perhaps previous reviewers were using a program that requires an Xinput gamepad which would possibly require the switch on the back of the controller being switched from D to X but most programs are compatible with either so not 100% sure… it works on Steam for sure

data.title: Stands up to my nonsense
data.body:
Bottom line - this thing is basic, plain and wired but Oh my gosh is it durable!! I game with my kids and husband but I’m not a natural gamer so I suck at walking in basically every game. I played Skyrim for a decade on Xbox before my husband bought a new laptop and I inherited his old laptop and learned about PC gaming.

But I still can’t walk and the WASD thing and my mouse are too hard for me. I’m a level 47 Grandma, the learning curve is slow sometimes so I have to use a controller.

While I’ve only played Skyrim, Subnautica, No Mans Sky and Minecraft - I use this controller for all of them and it works great! My husband hates it, he feels like it’s too … choppy? When he uses the controller, but for someone like me, it’s perfect bc it’s not too sensitive.

But mostly - I drop it. Like every freaking day. Like at least 3-5 times a day. On to a hard faux wood floor. Every single dang day. Because I’m ridiculous and always have too many things in my lap and stand up and forget or I’ll get caught on the cord or I’ll set the controller down and gravity takes hold and it falls off the desk. Y’all don’t even understand how serious I am about how often I drop this thing - and yet, it’s still reliable. Still there for me every day as I lay each individual block in an effort to create the perfect survival base and earn all my achievements, just a few more years to go and I have a feeling this controller will keep taking that journey with me ;)

data.title: Cheap but servicable
data.body: This has some wiggle to the control stick and isn't the most comfortable controller I've held, but for the price it's good and I've had no issues with it.

data.title: Love it
data.body: Got for my grandson so he could play games on the computer and wouldn’t have to use keyboard. He told me that he LOVED it.

data.title: Best controller ever
data.body: It is the best controller I have for my PC ever and have not had an issue yet

data.title: A little farkle for my new laptop
data.body: I got a new gaming laptop for the holidays. All these years of using windows and it never occurred to me that an XBOX controller would just plug and play into it. Saw this controller on sale and thought it would be a good accessory. Shipped and arrived quickly, no batteries, just plug and play. Works perfect with all my games so far (Fallout, Wolfenstein, Dying Light 2 and Dishonered 2) to name a few. The feel in hand is good , feedback is great. Very nice controller at a good price.

data.title: Great
data.body: Great

data.title: Play Station style Controller
data.body: Works great. Replaced one I’ve had for 10 years.

data.title: Very good coontroller for pc
data.body: Simple.

data.title: 1 year review. Surprisingly still works!
data.body:
It's a cheap controller with mid-2000's style. It's not the most confortable. It's not wireless (and even its bigger brother, the F710 isn't bluetooth), no motion sensors, and it hasn't been updated since its introduction.
HOWEVER, it absolutely demolishes most other controllers out there on what matters. It works.
I've read ludicrous stories of its reliability, like someone spilling hypercaffeinated, hypersugary coffee and then powerwashing it, and it still worked but i had to give it a try. Since my purchase, it has seen much use, but it continues to work while other, more expensive options (looking at you, Nintendo) would have broken down with just regular use. I *may* have dropped it a couple of times...ok a bit more than a couple but it took it like a champ.
Only gripe with it that causes me to give it a 4 star review is that the driver that comes with it hasn't been updated since 2010, and prevents Windows 11 from engaging the Memory Integrity function.
All in all, pretty satisfied with my purchase.

data.title: Excellent for emulation
data.body:
I want to finally beat Super Mario Brothers 3 and Super Castlevania 4, and this might be the controller that I do it with. One thing I always disliked about Nintendo systems was the controllers. The NES had that square one that felt like a torture device. The SNES had a rounded one, but I didn't love it. This one feels perfect, and I actually feel like I'm better at SNES games. At the very least, I don't want to put them down because of controller discomfort. The app is good, it lets you remap everything.

I'm not a "pro" gamer, so I can't tell you about all the finer points of controller design and competitive play, but it works well for my casual needs. I also like that it's not wireless. I just pick it up and play, no batteries or pairing nonsense to contend with.

data.title: Great for online gaming!
data.body: Very comfortable controller. Well made. Good action. Highly recommended for your gaming go-to!

data.title: good for the money
data.body: Not as accurate as I would like, but for the money it's great

data.title: feels good
data.body: This is nice and sturdy this is my second one

data.title: Why spend big money when this one does the job?
data.body:
I've always spent $70 or more to get my favorite, the authentic Xbox controller. After the 3rd one broke down, I decided to try this logitech one. It's p
Pretty cheap, and I got it on sale, so even better. After a few weeks, I'm thus far completely satisfied. Everything works well, and I'm satisfied with the materials quality. Will not go back to original, premium console controllers.

data.title: It’s alright
data.body:
Okay so this controller fits comfortably in your hands. It’s like a PlayStation controller. It works well with steam and emulation. If you are a casual player, play Jrpg this is a great controller for you. If you are doing a platforming or a bit hard on your controller then this is probably the controller for you.

The bad? I played Celeste and Dark Souls 1 (platformer) and this wrecked the controller. My ps5 controller and GameSir controller has held up with playing Celeste and other games. My PlayStation 5 controller gave out a little after a year and half but this controller gave out in three months. This is strange because I had this controller before that I bought years ago and it was just fine (until it wasn’t which is why I got the replacement) and this new controller hardly lasted. It was stick drift for the first one one. It was the R1 button got stuck and I would be randomly striking things for the second one. I tried cleaning it to and there was no resolution.

data.title: I mean, it works
data.body:
I gave it 4 stars, where really it should be 3. This thing is very uncomfortable to use and has a very awkward design for the underside of the controller. I used it for about 30 minutes and I was over it. I gave it 4 stars because it does work well and the price being so cheap earned it another. I used it for a silly application, so I’m not upset about it not being great.

If you really need something cheap that works, then this is at least an option. If you need something that won’t kill your hands and for long sessions I absolutely cannot recommend this

data.title: It’s comfy
data.body: It’s comfy but sometimes doesn’t work on steam games? Maybe it’s a steam issue

data.title: Great Game Controller
data.body: It works for both PC and laptops!

data.title: It's... it's just awful. Like the limp handshake of the controller world.
data.body:
Yeah, I mean, looking back, what did I expect for less than twenty bucks? But still. I thought a big brand like Logitech would do a little better than this.

For starters, every single element (excluding the D-pad) has its own unique amount of resistance. This is especially true of the bottom triggers AND the joysticks. The left stick is almost limp, while the right stick is so stiff it'll give your thumb a workout. The bottom triggers also have two completely different "feels." It's like each piece was sourced from an entirely different factory. It's just enough chaos to totally confuse your brain.

And - can we talk about these absolutely BIZARRE triggers? The top triggers are clicky and shallow. The only thing I can compare them to would be the "Start" and "Select" buttons on my old DSLite. Fine for buttons you're going to press once every half hour, but certainly not for triggers. The bottom triggers, meanwhile, are SO weird. Their axis of rotation is so unnatural - almost like I've got to press them on the far side instead of the face (if that makes sense). There is also nowhere for your fingers to rest or hook on to them. These things are actively finger-hostile. I tried playing an FPS and my hands threw a fit. (Okay, okay... *I* threw a fit.)

And the ergonomics! Or rather, the complete lack thereof. This thing just feels awkward - horribly, heinously awkward. The thumb sticks are so tall that I have to stretch my thumbs to get a hold of them. There's nowhere for my fingers to go, especially my index fingers which, as I've said, can't play nice with the triggers.

This controller is also EXTREMELY lightweight. I know, I know - heft does not equal quality. But I'm not talking about quality here. I'm talking about the fact that it feels like holding a hollow, dead fish. At least put some rocks in it or something.

I know I'm used to AAA console controllers these days, and this thing never claimed to be a DualShock4... but there's some serious quality and design issues going on here. Maybe it works for other people's hands, but it certainly doesn't work for mine. The inconsistency of the joysticks is particularly unforgiveable.

With all of that said, this is the best D-pad I've ever used. Switches feel nice and non-mushy, and are very consistent. If you only play games that just use the D-pad, this might work for you.

data.title: The best
data.body: Have been using it since it was delivered yesterday. It works great, been using it to play Forza Horizon on PC.

data.title: Frustrating, Uncomfortable. EasySMX ESM-9100 is much better.
data.body:
The Logitech F310 is not so great. The D-pad is "floaty" and loose (I mean rattling loose), and will actually press up and down at the same time, which should be impossible but the innards are so cheap, it does it anyway! The triggers are very stiff. The other buttons are just stubborn about working during combo presses. Anything that requires timed or multiple buttons, is hit or miss, mostly miss, and will just randomly fail sometimes no matter how careful and deliberately you press them. Absolutely the most frustrating controller I've ever used as far as buttons just not responding 2, 3 times in row.

This controller "fails" after every reboot with a dreaded "!" in device manager and an error about "this device cannot start". I have to unplug it, reboot, re-plug and let it get re-detected every time for it to work, until the next reboot. I had an F310 YEARS ago that did the same thing! It was the reason I eventually trashed that one. These things are junk! Plain and simple.

It has a long throw (too tall) analog sticks. Makes your thumbs bash into each other. In my photos, it is compared to the EasySMX ESM-9100 (Xbox style - get this instead), and the ZD-V+ (best D-Pad, very PSX-like) so a little about those if they are on your "maybe list".

1. The EasySMX ESM-9100: Very good controller (xinput+dinput), way better than the F310 overall, especially if you prefer the Xbox style. Feels solid and of "OEM" quality. It is in the same price range with the F310 but is a superior controller in every way.

2. The ZD-V+: Good, but flawed controller (xinput+dinput). Still better than the F310 not as good as EasySMX. Had it for ~12 years. Buttons are (always were) a little sticky feeling but function fine, and the analog sticks not very precise and have a longer "throw" (tall stick) that I don't care for. The "triggers" are pressure (not-so)sensitive buttons that function more like on/off buttons than analog triggers. Edit: this one developed coil whine after ~12 years and is now in the trash.

Edit: Another one I have gotten since this was the Beitong BAT 2. That one has the best analog sticks I have ever seen! 0.9% error report in gamepad tester at "hardwaretester com/gamepad". A typical good controller scores 10.0-20.0%. Sadly, the D-Pad on it is not so good. Lots of accidental/false diagonal presses, but for games that only use D-Pad for menu stuff, etc., it's very nice!
